What is Stunting ? Stunting is a condition of failure to thrive in children under five years of age (toddlers) due to chronic lack of nutritional intake and recurrent infections, especially during the First 1,000 Days of Life (HPK), namely from the fetus to the child aged 23 months. Stunting is determined by an anthropometric index that uses body length data based on age (PB/U) for children under 2 years of age and uses height based on age data (TB/U) for children aged 2 years and over.
What are the characteristics of stunting? - Growth slows down, Face looks younger than children his age, Delayed tooth growth, Poor performance in focus ability and learning memory, Age 8-10 years children become quieter , dont make much eye contact with people around them, The toddlers weight does not increase and even tends to decrease, The childs body development is hampered, such as late menarche (a girls first menstruation). The child is easily attacked by various infectious diseases.
What are the impacts of stunting? There are many losses that children experience if they experience stunting. The short-term impacts of stunting on children aged 0-5 are: (1) The child gets sick easily, (2) The childs growth and development is hampered, for example the child is late in talking or walking. Apart from that, stunting also has long-term impacts, namely (1) When you go to school, your learning ability decreases, which has a negative impact on learning achievement; (2) Obesity/overweight; (3) When you grow up, your chances of getting a decent job are reduced; (4) Have a higher risk of developing non-communicable diseases, such as diabetes mellitus, heart disease, etc..
Can stunting be prevented or corrected? Stunting can be prevented or corrected if done before or during the golden period. Therefore, various important interventions are carried out from an early age, starting from preparing the nutritional and health conditions of the expectant mother to ensuring good health and adequate nutrition, especially in the first 1000 days of life, namely from the time the child is in the womb until the age of 2 years.
